results.title: Let's look at railways
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film outlines the importance of railways to Australia. It shows the Australian railway system as an important means of transport for primary products, mail and people; traces the history of rail transport from the time of the Industrial Revolution; the effect of introducing railway transport in Australia; the break of gauge problems; the development of powerful locomotives in various states to cope with modern heavy haulages; the future of railways in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Fire brigade
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of training a young recruit in every aspect of his duty as a fireman attached to a large metropolitan fire brigade. Equipment is demonstrated in detail, including its actual use in a spectacular city fire.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Farewell to charms
results.creator_credit: Carla Pontiac, Carole Sklan and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: An experimental feminist film which questions the goals of love and romance as a woman’s ultimate fulfillment. Emma, vivacious but suicidal terrorist is reunited with Cecily, her old school chum. They meet a ‘bionic bike dyke’ called stretch and break open the jelly beans. Will they stretch a point over the pool table? Will tap-dancing and vaginal exercises be enough for Cecily? Will Emma metamorphose into Esther Williams? True romance. Cast includes Radda Jordan, Helen Pankhurst.

results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.

results.title: Children's Theatre
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Children at the Studio Theatre in Adelaide study painting, music and speech as part of their training in ballet. This is a Children’s Theatre for children and by children. Classes and rehearsals, planning and teaching precede the performance of an Australian ballet, telling the story of an Australian aboriginal legend.

results.title: Beyond the boom: metal mining in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle, Australian Mining Industry Council and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The evolution of mining in Australia from the first gold discoveries to the iron, nickel and copper developments of the 1960’s , its historic importance in national growth and economic stability and in the exploration and settling of much of Australia. The scope of modern mining and processing industries, exploration and prospecting, the growth of new towns and stimulation of regional development.

results.title: Australian by design
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The manufacture of Australia’s own car from the initial design on a drawing board to the completed vehicle as it comes off the assembly line. Precedence is given to safety in both design and engineering. Rigorous tests are carried out at Lang Lang testing track which incorporates all types of road conditions. In creating an automotive industry G.M.H. has stimulated the nation’s industries and economy.

results.title: Anzac
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Historical photographs and early newsreels tell the story of the Gallipoli assault; embarkation and transport of 75,000 men in 200 ships from Egypt to Gallipoli; initial landing below cliffs; building a jetty and digging in; main British attack at Cape Helles and subsequent assaults on the heights; hardships, casualties and final evacuation. Commentary by Moray Powell and Peter Carver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films

Commentary by Moray Powell and Peter Carver.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Greg Barnett]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

After graudating in computer science from Melbourne University, Greg Bennett joined Beam Software in 1982. Inspired by his dual interests in programming and film, Bennett designed and programmed the groundbreaking one-on-one martial arts game ‘The Way of the exploding fist’. He talks about the game industry over the years and the changes, both financial and creative, in relation to his career.

results.title: Rhythm
results.brief_description:
Originally planned as a work for Chrysler Corporation’s weekly television program, ‘Rhythm’ presents a montage of the factory workers, machinery and materials on a car production assembly line.
Lye has edited his footage with a staccato feel that he has matched with the percussive music used for the soundtrack.
Although rejected by Chrysler, the film won first prize in the television category in the 1957 New York Art Directors’ Festival but was subsequently disqualified because it had never been broadcast.
